Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Papaverine Concentrations for Vasospasm Prevention in Radial Artery Grafts

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, RA segments were harvested from 10 CABG patients at John Paul II Hospital.

Participants.evidence: RA segments were harvested from 10 CABG patients at John Paul II Hospital.

Intervention.evidence: The segments were randomly assigned to two groups: 0.5 mg/ml papaverine (n=12) and 2 mg/ml papaverine (n=12).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the efficacy of two papaverine concentrations (0.5 mg/ml and 2 mg/ml) for vasospasm prevention and their impact on endothelial integrity in radial artery (RA) grafts used in coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was vasodilatory effect, assessed using ex vivo myography over 60 minutes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The segments were randomly assigned to two groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The segments were randomly assigned to two groups: 0.5 mg/ml papaverine (n=12) and 2 mg/ml papaverine (n=12).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 2 mg/ml papaverine group showed stronger vasodilatation (mean difference = 24.67%, 95% CI 15.23 to 34.11; p < 0.001) but caused more endothelial damage (mean difference = 22.63%, 95% CI 8.91 to 36.35; p = 0.002) compared to the 0.5 mg/ml group.
